Everyone:

I've heard for years people talking about the importance of being able 
to find all the tests for a given class. I have never cared about this, 
so I'm surprised when so many other people do care about it. Either 
they're missing something simple, or I'm missing something simple.

Let's say I want to know which tests cover a given production code 
method. To do that, I go to the method, then hit Shift+Ctrl+G in 
Eclipse, searching the workspace for references to that method. It's 
usually pretty easy to scan the list of search results and separate the 
test case classes (which have the word "Test" in them) from the 
production code classes (which don't have the word "Test" in them). This 
technique has never posed a serious enough problem for me to want to do 
it a different way.

I have used the same technique with IntelliJ IDEA, so it's not just an 
Eclipse thing.

I can also do the same thing if I want to see which tests use the 
/class/, but I can't remember the last time I wanted to know that. I 
typically want to know which tests are using a /method/, not a class.

So would anyone like to tell us a story of when they needed to search 
for the tests that cover a given production code class, and how 
organizing their tests their way made that easy? I'd like to learn what 
the big issues are.

Thanks.
